place.desc: 安禅寺 山西省, 普中市，太谷县 Ānchánsì ZGWWDTJ, Shanxi vol. 3 (xia), p. 762 57 – C 1 (On Anchansi street in Taigu County Seat• Song, Ming dynasties •Provincial Cultural Heritage Site) Date of initial founding unknown. According to an inscription, the complex was rebuilt in the Song dynasty, with repairs made in the Yuan and Ming dynasties as well as in the third year of the Qing Guangxu reign period (1877). The complex occupies 200 square meters. Buildings are oriented to the south, the monastic cloister has been destroyed, all that remains are two axial buildings, the Sutra Repository (Cángjīngdiàn (藏经殿)) and the Main Hall (Zhèngdiàn (正殿)). Of the remaining buildings, the Sutra Repository is a artifact of the Song dynasty; the Main Hall is a Ming dynasty building. The front façade of the Main Hall is 3 bays in width with a depth of 6 rafters, and has a single eaves, overhanging gable roof, 7 purlin-no gallery style design, 3-step, single ang bracket sets (sancai danang 三踩单昂), with one intercolumnar bracket set in each bay. Translated by Lydia Ohl; modified TM 7/28/10; 9/19/11; Edited by Cole Garrett 9/9/11;

Ānchánsì ZGWWDTJ, Shanxi vol. 3 (xia), p. 762 57 – C 1-1 Sutra Repository (cángjīngdiàn/藏经殿 (Song Dynasty)) Brick podium, front façade of 3 bays, depth of 3 bays, single eaves hip/gable roof, yellow and green glazed tiles with a square center, wide central bay and narrow side bays, central bay is only one half the width of the side bay. Under eave bracket sets are 4 pūzuò with a single huágŏng, a locust head shuătóu, 1 intercolumnar bracket set in every bay, and visible column-top entasis. Original renovation no longer exists. Translated by Lydia Ohl; modified TM 7/28/10; 9/19/11; Edited by Cole Garrett 9/9/11
